Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: COSEE: Ocean Systems - Building Capacity Through Collaboration
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides renewed funding for the Centers for Ocean Science Education Excellence - Ocean Systems (COSEE-OS). Through its ongoing efforts, COSEE-OS has identified key areas for future growth, including: (i) facilitating the creation of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) resources that are conceptually linked to ocean-climate content; (ii) scaling up ocean scientists' impacts by taking advantage of networking infrastructure; and (iii) building tools to assess the quality of consensus-based products created by diverse communities.

The Center will expand its successful model of creating software that is flexible, transferrable, and user focused for the ocean science community. OS will share this model via workshops for scientists at other COSEE's. OS will scale up its regional initiatives to have national impact, with a focus on rural and inland audiences. In addition, a new partnership with the Institute for Broadening Participation is improving engagement of underrepresented minorities in OS opportunities, and will serve as a model for the greater Network. By supporting existing educational programs, OS will assist two small, but prestigious, research laboratories -- Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory and Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences -- in meeting their goal of providing effective research experiences for K-12 educators and "young scientists" in training. The Center's goal is to build Capacity nationwide, honing individuals' abilities to develop effective "Broader Impacts" (BI) activities. This is accomplished, in part, by engaging informal education institution partners such as Seacoast Science Center (SSC) and New England Aquarium (NEAq) to aid in the development of BI activities with scientists. The Center also supports the New England Ocean Sciences Education Collaborative (NEOSEC), a diverse network of over 40 organizations coordinated by NEAq, to build regional capacity by training its educators in planning and implementing BI activities for ocean scientists. This ensures that the content and products of current ocean science research can efficiently reach a broad audience in a timely fashion.

A newly formalized partnership with the Northeastern Regional Association of Coastal and Ocean Observing Systems (NERACOOS) unites the New England cadre of ocean science educators and their students to the NERACOOS scientists, providing opportunities to increase the BI for scientists. The Center's joint efforts with New England regional Sea Grant Extension staff to field test new analytical tools that aid consensus building about climate change issues in New England coastal communities is another opportunity for scientists to increase their BI activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Ocean Systems (OS) was funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) Centers for Ocean Sciences Education Excellence (COSEE) program. With its key partner organizations – University of Maine (UMaine), University of New Hampshire, New England Aquarium, and Institute for Broadening Participation (IBP) – COSEE-OS met all of its major goals and objectives in the areas of Innovation & Excellence, Reach, Pipeline, and Capacity.

Innovation & Excellence

A fundamental activity was creating and testing innovative software (cosee.umaine.edu) that could be used by the COSEE Network and beyond, including the Concept-Linked Integrated Media Builder (CLIMB) software. CLIMB has had over 442,000 pageviews with average session durations of 11 minutes, far exceeding the generally accepted industry standard goal of 2-3 minutes. Overall, CLIMB has 4,660 registered users who have created a total of 11,146 concept maps. These data demonstrate that CLIMB keeps users engaged, nurtures their interests, and gets them to make their own custom concept maps.

In addition to being a flexible tool that thousands of users have accessed for their own purposes, CLIMB was employed for dozens of COSEE-OS webinars and workshops. The efficacy of concept mapping, and use of CLIMB in particular, towards meeting COSEE goals has been documented in several publications (deCharon, 2010 and 2014; deCharon et al., 2013, 2015a, and 2015b). To sustain use of CLIMB over time, its final version is responsive on mobile devices.

Capacity

Building the capacity of educators and scientists to understand and communicate about ocean sciences to diverse audiences was a cornerstone of COSEE-OS. Early trainings were provided during in-person events and, over time, such opportunities were offered as online courses and webinars.

In-person capacity-building events were planned and executed with partner organizations and other COSEE Centers. COSEE-OS led 38 in-person workshops that trained over 1000 total participants. Events focused on developing broader impacts skills and, in some cases, practicing these skills on target audiences. Several workshops followed the COSEE-OS developed model, Faculty-Graduate Student Collaborative, which is documented in deCharon et al. (2013).  COSEE-OS was also a key player in the “Gears” workshop model led by COSEE Networked Ocean World.

Effective practices from these capacity-building endeavors were folded into an online graduate course, “Broaden the Impacts of Your Research,” developed and instructed by the COSEE-OS Principal Investigator. This highly transferrable, semester-long offering was added to the UMaine graduate curriculum in 2015.

Reach

OS led the COSEE Network in terms of developing and executing effective webinar series including: “Research-based Online Learning Event (ROLE) Model” webinars, the “North Atlantic Bloom Experiment,”  “Benthic Ecology,” “Turbulence,” “Marine Debris,” and “GEOTRACES.” Each series featured multiple investigators who addressed linked, societally relevant topics. To sustain participants’ interest, the Center provided readily accessible resources for post-event learning. Furthermore, webinar archives and materials were made available through the COSEE-OS website, reaching thousands of people who were unable to attend live sessions.

COSEE-OS webinar series consisted of 32 live events with 1,054 total participants in 41 states, District of Columbia (DC), and Puerto Rico. Individuals also joined from 14 Non-US countries. The impact of COSEE-OS webinar series went well beyond the live events. Overall, 15% the total COSEE-OS website traffic (253,800 pageviews) was webinar archive pages, attesting to the popularity and broad reach of resources created for these events.

Pipeline

Supporting individuals along the academic pipeline was a significant activity for COSEE-OS. Over the years, the Center’s focus shifted from pre-college to higher education audiences. However, the involvement of graduate students was consistent throughout the life of the grant.

COSEE-OS facilitated collaboration between UMaine’s School of Marine Sciences and three school districts in Maine. This multi-year endeavor supported varied activities at laboratories along with professional development opportunities for graduate students and educators using COSEE tools and resources (e.g., “Teaching Physical Concepts in Oceanography” booklet).

COSEE-OS and IBP customized and implemented “Pathways” webinars to meet the needs of diverse people along the academic pipeline. These events provided practical advice for community college students interested in marine sciences undergraduate programs, undergraduates applying for summer research programs or graduate school, post-docs negotiating for new positions, among others. Faculty-level professionals were also supported through the “Be Inclusive” workshops and resulting documentation, the latter of which provides an overview of the research literature about positive factors that support success in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) pathways and reduce barriers to participation.

COSEE-OS and IBP co-facilitated 33 “Pathways” webinars, attended by nearly 1300 undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty-level participants. Individuals joined the webinars from 49 states, DC, Puerto Rico, and 17 non-US countries. These participants represented 313 universities, community colleges and research laboratories, including 12 Historically Black Colleges and Universities.
